title: RL30788
content: The Senate's procedures are based on standing rules, orders, precedents, statutes, mandates, committee rules, conference rules, and informal practices. Reference sources provide information on how these authorities govern parliamentary situations, establishing the framework for Senate business. This report discusses reference sources for Senate procedures, covering official documents outlining the rules. The report discusses reference sources like the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure that outline the Senate's procedural authorities and rules for conducting business. It also covers publications from Senate committees and party conferences on parliamentary procedures. The report covers Senate reference sources such as the Senate Manual, Riddick's Senate Procedure, and rules from Senate committees and party conferences. It reviews Senate parliamentary procedure principles and official reference sources that provide authoritative statements on Senate rules and precedents. The report reviews Senate parliamentary procedure principles and official reference sources that provide authoritative statements on Senate rules and precedents, including the Senate Manual, Riddick's Senate Procedure, and rules from Senate committees and party conferences. Additionally, it covers additional publications of committees and other offices of the Senate. The report provides access points to official reference sources on Senate rules, procedures, and precedents, including the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure. It also covers rules from Senate committees and party conferences, as well as additional publications from Senate offices. Text boxes offer guidance on accessing these sources, with an emphasis on online access for Senators and congressional staff. This report provides access points to official reference sources on Senate rules, procedures, and precedents, including the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure. Text boxes offer guidance on accessing these sources, with an emphasis on online access for Senators and congressional staff. Additionally, two appendixes supplement the information on parliamentary reference sources provided throughout the report. Appendix A provides a selected list of CRS products on Senate procedure. This report provides access points to official reference sources on Senate rules, procedures, and precedents. Two appendixes supplement the information, offering a selected list of CRS products on Senate procedure and an overview of primary websites for accessing resources. Basic familiarity with Senate procedures is assumed, with official guidance available from the Office of the Senate Parliamentarian. Senate staff can also assist with clarifying rules and procedures. The report provides access to official reference sources on Senate rules and procedures. Senate procedures derive from multiple sources, and the Senate has the power to make its own rules. The Senate applies regulations in accordance with principles applicable across parliamentary situations. The Senate applies regulations based on various parliamentary authorities and principles that are generally applicable. These principles include deriving procedures from multiple sources, having the power to make its own rules, initiating enforcement of rules by Senators, conducting business by unanimous consent, following precedents, and adhering to informal practices. The Senate follows various parliamentary authorities and principles in its procedures, including the power to make its own rules, enforcement initiated by Senators, conducting business by unanimous consent, following precedents, and adhering to informal practices. Other sources of Senate procedures include requirements from the Constitution, standing orders, statutory provisions, committee rules, and rules of the Senate. The Senate's parliamentary procedures are guided by various sources, including the rules of the Senate, requirements from the Constitution, standing orders, precedents, statutory provisions, committee rules, party conference rules, procedural agreements, and informal practices. These sources collectively shape the Senate's decision-making processes. The Senate's procedures are influenced by rules, precedents, and customs, including recognition priorities for Senators. The Senate's rules prioritize recognition for Senators, giving precedence to the majority and minority leaders and managers. This practice can impact Senate proceedings by allowing the majority leader to make key motions or propose amendments. Understanding this Senate tradition is essential for comprehending how the Senate conducts its business. The Senate's rules prioritize recognition for Senators, allowing the majority leader to make key motions or propose amendments. Article I of the Constitution gives the Senate the authority to determine its rules of procedure, with the Senate having the power to decide on its procedures through majority vote. The Senate has the authority to determine its rules of procedure through majority vote, including amending standing rules and creating new ones. This rulemaking power extends to standing orders and rulemaking provisions in statutes like the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The Senate can determine its rules of procedure through majority vote, including creating standing orders and rulemaking provisions in statutes. It can also waive its rules by unanimous consent or suspend them under Senate Rule V. The Senate can determine its rules of procedure through majority vote, including creating standing orders and rulemaking provisions in statutes. It can also waive its rules by unanimous consent or suspend them under Senate Rule V. The chamber can decide when its rules should not govern, waiving rules by unanimous consent or suspending them with a two-thirds vote. The Senate lacks a mechanism to supersede rules by majority vote like the House can with a "special rule." The Senate can waive its rules by a two-thirds vote or by overruling the presiding officer's decision. This sets a precedent for future rulings. The Senate can overrule the presiding officer's decision by majority vote, setting a precedent for future rulings. The presiding officer may not always point out violations of Senate rules, but a Senator can make a point of order to challenge proposed actions. The Senate's presiding officer may not always call attention to violations of Senate rules, but a Senator can challenge proposed actions by making a point of order. The presiding officer typically makes a ruling without debate when a point of order is raised. When a point of order is raised in the Senate, the presiding officer usually makes a ruling without debate. Any Senator can appeal the ruling, and the Senate may decide by majority vote to uphold or overturn it. The presiding officer can also submit a question of order for the Senate's decision if existing rules and precedents are unclear. When a point of order is raised in the Senate, the presiding officer can submit a question for the Senate's decision. Any Senator can appeal the ruling, and the Senate may uphold or overturn it by majority vote, establishing a precedent for future decisions. Some rules require a supermajority vote to overturn the presiding officer's ruling. When a point of order is raised in the Senate, the presiding officer's decision can be overturned by a majority vote, setting a precedent for future decisions. Some rules may require a supermajority vote to overturn the ruling. Parliamentary actions based on informal practices or party conference rules are not enforceable on the Senate floor. Parliamentary actions based on informal practices or party conference rules are not enforceable on the Senate floor as they do not have the authority of Senate rules and procedures. Informal practices evolve over time as custom, while party conference rules are adopted and enforced by each party. The Senate's standing rules emphasize the rights of individual Senators, including the right to debate at length. The Senate's standing rules emphasize individual Senators' rights, such as the right to debate at length and offer relevant amendments. To expedite legislation, the Senate often operates outside its standing rules by unanimous consent. The Senate frequently operates under unanimous consent agreements to expedite legislation, allowing for the consideration of measures and amendments with careful crafting to avoid objections from individual Senators. Senate business is often conducted under unanimous consent agreements, which are carefully crafted by the majority leader in consultation with other key Senators. These agreements allow for the consideration of measures and amendments with the requirement that no Senator objects. UC agreements in the Senate are meticulously crafted by the majority leader in consultation with key Senators and committee leaders. They are orally presented on the floor and take effect unless objected to. Once in place, UC agreements hold the same authority as Senate rules and can only be changed by unanimous consent. UC agreements in the Senate, crafted by the majority leader and key Senators, have the same authority as Senate rules and can only be altered by unanimous consent. Published Senate precedents interpret and supplement rules, providing guidance on their application. The Senate's published precedents interpret and supplement its rules, serving as a crucial guide for understanding proceedings. Similar to case law, these precedents are cited by Senators to support arguments and points of order. The Senate's precedents, like case law, play a crucial role in determining proceedings by influencing how current rules are applied. Senators cite precedents to support arguments, points of order, and appeals, while the presiding officer uses them to justify rulings. Precedents in the Senate influence the application of current rules by referencing past decisions to support arguments, points of order, and appeals. These precedents are established through Senate votes on questions of order or when the presiding officer makes a ruling that is not appealed. Precedents in the Senate are established through votes on questions of order or rulings by the presiding officer. The Senate follows these precedents until a decision is reversed or modified. Precedents can also be set when the presiding officer responds to a parliamentary inquiry, but they do not carry equal weight due to the Senate's ultimate authority over its rules. Precedents in the Senate are established through votes or rulings by the presiding officer. The Senate follows these precedents until a decision is reversed or modified. Precedents based on a vote of the full Senate carry more weight than those based on rulings of the presiding officer. Responses to parliamentary inquiries have even less weight as they are not subject to appeal by the full Senate. In the Senate, precedents based on a vote of the full Senate are more authoritative than those based on rulings of the presiding officer. Responses to parliamentary inquiries have even less weight as they cannot be appealed by the full Senate. Recent precedents hold more weight than earlier ones, and established patterns of rulings carry more weight than isolated precedents. All precedents must be evaluated in the historical context of the Senate's rules and practices. In the Senate, precedents based on a vote of the full Senate are more authoritative than those based on rulings of the presiding officer. Recent precedents hold more weight than earlier ones, and established patterns of rulings carry more weight than isolated precedents. All precedents must be evaluated in the historical context of the Senate's rules and practices. Senators seeking precedents may consult the Senate Parliamentarian's Office for support or rebuttal. Some Senate procedural actions are based on unofficial practices that have evolved over the years and become accepted custom. Some Senate procedural actions are based on unofficial practices that have evolved over the years and become accepted custom. These practices do not have the same standing as the chamber's rules, nor are they compiled in any written source of authority. Although these unofficial practices cannot be enforced on the Senate floor, many of them are well established and customarily followed. Some unofficial Senate practices, not enforceable on the Senate floor, include respecting "holds" by individual Senators and giving the majority leader the authority to make motions. The Senate Manual compiles official parliamentary authorities. The Senate Manual compiles official parliamentary authorities, including Standing Rules of the Senate and Nonstatutory Standing Orders. It is prepared under the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration and is periodically updated. The Senate Manual, prepared by the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, contains parliamentary authorities such as Standing Rules of the Senate, Nonstatutory Standing Orders, Rules for Regulation of the Senate Wing, Rules of Procedure in Impeachment Trials, Cleaves' Manual, and General Laws Relating to the U.S. Senate. The Senate Manual includes rules and regulations affecting the business of the Senate, procedures for impeachment trials, and laws relating to the U.S. Senate. It also contains Cleaves' Manual on conferences and conference reports, as well as the Constitution of the United States of America. The Senate Manual includes rules and regulations, procedures for impeachment trials, and laws relating to the U.S. Senate. It also contains Cleaves' Manual on conferences and conference reports, as well as the Constitution of the United States of America. The Manual provides detailed information on each authority, with section numbers running throughout in a single sequence and always appearing in bold type. The Senate Manual contains rules, regulations, and procedures for impeachment trials, with section numbers assigned in a single sequence. The Manual also includes Cleaves' Manual on conferences, the Constitution of the United States, and provides detailed information on each authority. Section numbers are used for citation instead of page numbers. The Senate Manual contains rules and procedures for impeachment trials, with section numbers for citation. The Senate does not re-adopt its standing rules at the beginning of each new Congress, as it considers its rules to be continuous. The Senate regards its rules as continuous without re-adopting them at the start of each new Congress. Changes to the standing rules are proposed through Senate resolutions and can be adopted by majority vote. At the beginning of the 116th Congress, there were 44 standing rules of the Senate outlined in the Manual. At the start of the 116th Congress, there were 44 standing rules of the Senate outlined in the Manual. The rules can be amended through Senate resolutions adopted by majority vote, with footnotes indicating changes since 1979. The Manual includes a detailed table of contents and index for easy reference. Occasionally, the Senate may establish standing orders through resolutions or unanimous consent requests. The Senate can amend its standing rules through resolutions adopted by majority vote, with footnotes indicating changes since 1979. Standing orders, created by resolutions or unanimous consent requests, have the same authority as standing rules and remain in effect until repealed by the Senate. A standing order of the Senate operates with the same authority as a standing rule and is enforceable on the Senate floor. It remains in effect until repealed by the Senate and is compiled in the Manual in sections 60-139. This compilation includes the text, subject matter, and citation to the Senate resolution(s) that created it. The Manual compiles permanent standing orders of the Senate in sections 60-139, providing text, subject matter, and citation to Senate resolutions. It also includes a compilation of "General and Permanent Laws Relating to the U.S. Senate." The Manual compiles permanent standing orders of the Senate in sections 60-139, providing text, subject matter, and citation to Senate resolutions. It also includes a compilation of "General and Permanent Laws Relating to the U.S. Senate," presenting statutory excerpts in their codified version without citation or commentary. The Manual compiles permanent standing orders of the Senate in sections 60-139, providing text, subject matter, and citation to Senate resolutions. It includes statutory excerpts in their codified version without citation or commentary, addressing Senate administration, operations, and procedural matters. The Manual compiles Senate procedures and rules, including Senators' oaths of office, officers of the Senate, and investigative procedures in Senate committees. It also covers rulemaking statutes that establish procedures for Senate action on specified measures. The U.S. Constitution imposes procedural requirements on the Senate, such as keeping and publishing an official Journal of its proceedings and requiring a majority quorum for conducting business on the Senate floor. The U.S. Constitution imposes procedural requirements on the Senate, including keeping an official Journal of proceedings, requiring a majority quorum for business, and mandating yea and nay votes. The Senate has exclusive powers like providing advice and consent for treaties and nominations. The Senate must maintain a majority quorum for business and conduct yea and nay votes upon request. It has exclusive powers to advise on treaties and nominations, and to try impeachments. The Manual provides the text of the Constitution and its amendments, with historical footnotes on ratification. The Senate has the sole power to try impeachments, as stated in Article I, Section 3 of the Constitution. The Manual includes the text of the Constitution and its amendments, with bold brackets around amended text and historical footnotes on ratification. Senate Rule XXXIII allows the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration to make rules for the Capitol complex. The Senate Rule XXXIII allows the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration to make rules for the Capitol complex, including regulations for floor activity and press galleries. The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration has the authority to make regulations for the Capitol complex, including rules for floor activity and press galleries. This includes regulations on floor duties, legislative buzzers, signal lights, and the use of display materials in the Senate chamber. Additionally, the Senate has special rules for impeachment trials referred to it by the House of Representatives. The Senate has adopted special rules for impeachment trials referred by the House of Representatives, including regulations on floor duties, legislative buzzers, signal lights, and display materials in the Senate chamber. These rules are treated as permanently in effect unless altered by the Senate. Amendments have been adopted on occasion. Cleaves' Manual provides a digest of rules and precedents governing Senate practice related to conference committees and reports. The Senate has special rules for impeachment trials from the House, including regulations on floor duties, buzzers, lights, and display materials. These rules remain in effect unless altered by the Senate. Cleaves' Manual summarizes rules and precedents for Senate practice regarding conference committees and reports. Cleaves' Manual summarizes rules and precedents for Senate practice regarding conference committees and reports, including excerpts from Thomas Jefferson's Manual of Parliamentary Practice. The principles outlined in Cleaves' Manual, which includes excerpts from Thomas Jefferson's Manual of Parliamentary Practice, still apply to current Senate practice. The Manual also includes statements by Vice Presidents and Speakers, Senate rules, precedents, and forms for conference reports. The excerpt below displays the format of the Manual and key features for use. Riddick's Senate Procedure, known as Riddick's, is a comprehensive reference source for Senate rules, precedents, and practices. It includes rules, principles, and forms for conference reports. The Manual presents the Constitution and explains key features for using the reference. Riddick's Senate Procedure, commonly known as Riddick's, is a comprehensive reference covering Senate rules, precedents, and practices. It distinguishes between Manual section numbers in bold text and Manual page numbers at the bottom of the page. The current edition, published in 1992, includes Senate precedents from 1883 to 1992, authored by Floyd M. Riddick and Alan S. Frumin. Riddick's Senate Procedure, also known as Riddick's, is a comprehensive reference presenting Senate precedents established from 1883 to 1992. It was authored by Floyd M. Riddick and Alan S. Frumin, organized around procedural topics in alphabetical order. Riddick's Senate Procedure, also known as Riddick's, is a comprehensive reference presenting Senate precedents established from 1883 to 1992. It is organized around procedural topics in alphabetical order, providing summaries of general principles and relevant rules for each topic. The volume presents a summary of general principles governing various topics, followed by relevant standing rules, constitutional provisions, or rulemaking provisions of statute. Summaries of principles established by individual precedents are organized in alphabetical order under subject headings and subtopics. For example, the topic "Cloture Procedure" includes subtopics like "Amendments After Cloture." Footnotes provide citations to the date, Congress, and session when each precedent was established. The curr_chunk discusses how footnotes in Riddick's Senate provide citations to the date, Congress, and session when each precedent was established, as well as where readers can locate the pertinent proceedings. It also explains that footnote citations indicate proceedings based on presiding officers' responses to parliamentary inquiries or precedents created by rulings or votes of the Senate. The curr_chunk provides information on how readers can locate pertinent proceedings in journal pages, with examples of citations indicating proceedings based on presiding officers' responses or Senate rulings. It also mentions an appendix in Riddick's Senate Procedure containing sample floor dialogues and established forms used in the Senate. The curr_chunk discusses the appendix in Riddick's Senate Procedure, which includes sample floor dialogues and established forms used in the Senate for various parliamentary situations. It also provides useful supplementary information and a separate index. The publication's main index helps locate information on specific Senate procedural topics. The Senate establishes standing orders by resolution or unanimous consent requests, usually effective for a Congress or limited period. A package of standing orders is adopted at the start of each Congress. The Senate adopts standing orders through unanimous consent requests, typically effective for a Congress or limited period. These standing orders are not included in the Senate Manual but are published in the Congressional Record. For example, at the start of the 116th Congress in 2019, the Senate re-established 11 unanimous consent agreements on various topics. Standing orders in the Senate are adopted through unanimous consent agreements, not included in the Senate Manual but in the Congressional Record. For instance, at the beginning of the 116th Congress in 2019, 11 unanimous consent agreements were adopted, re-establishing standing orders from the previous Congress on various topics. These agreements serve as parliamentary authorities and establish conditions for floor consideration of specific measures, overriding regulations in relation to those measures. Unanimous consent agreements in the Senate establish conditions for floor consideration of specific measures, overriding regulations and setting parameters for debate, voting, and amendments. These agreements serve as parliamentary authorities and allow access to the Senate floor for Members' staff during proceedings. Unanimous consent agreements in the Senate override regulations and establish conditions for floor consideration of specific measures. These agreements set parameters for debate, voting, and amendments, serving as parliamentary authorities enforced just like the Senate's standing rules. Accepted agreements are printed in the Congressional Record and on the Senate's daily Calendar of Business. Unanimous consent agreements in the Senate are enforced like standing rules. They are propounded orally, printed in the Congressional Record, and listed in the Senate's daily Calendar of Business. Committee rules must be adopted and published in the Congressional Record by March 1 of each Congress. Committee rules, required by Rule XXVI, paragraph 2 of the Senate's standing rules, must be adopted and published in the Congressional Record by March 1 of each Congress. These rules cover important aspects of the legislative process, such as preparing committee reports and issuing subpoenas, and are enforced by the committees themselves. Subcommittees may also have their own supplemental rules. Committee rules do not override the Senate's standing rules. Committee rules, required by Rule XXVI, paragraph 2 of the Senate's standing rules, must be adopted and published in the Congressional Record by March 1 of each Congress. These rules cover important aspects of the legislative process, such as preparing committee reports and issuing subpoenas, and are enforced by the committees themselves. Subcommittees may also have their own supplemental rules. Committee rules do not override the Senate's standing rules. Each committee's rules appear in the Congressional Record on the day they are submitted for publication, and may also be published in committee prints or on their websites. The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration compiles a document each Congress that includes the committee rules. The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration compiles a document each Congress that includes the committee rules, which are required to be adopted and published in the Congressional Record by March 1. These rules cover important aspects of the legislative process and are enforced by the committees themselves. Additionally, committee rules do not override the Senate's standing rules. The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration issues a document each Congress compiling the rules of procedure adopted by all Senate committees, known as the Authority and Rules of Senate Committees. This document includes jurisdiction statements for each committee and information on public law affecting committee procedures. The Senate can establish procedural regulations through simple resolutions or provisions in statutory measures. The Senate can establish procedural regulations through simple resolutions or provisions in statutory measures, which require agreement between both houses. These procedures have the same standing as Senate and House rules. The Senate can establish procedural regulations through simple resolutions or provisions in statutory measures, which require agreement between both houses. These procedures have the same standing as Senate and House rules and are created through an exercise of each chamber's constitutional rulemaking authority. A statute or concurrent resolution containing "rulemaking provisions" often includes a section asserting the rulemaking authority of each chamber, which can be changed in the same manner as the rules of each House. Statutory rulemaking provisions in the Senate are mainly derived from Legislative Reorganization Acts and establish expedited procedures for specific classes of measures. These provisions assert the rulemaking authority of each chamber and can be changed through adoption of a simple resolution. Statutory rulemaking provisions in the Senate are mainly derived from Legislative Reorganization Acts and establish expedited procedures for specific classes of measures. These provisions can be changed through adoption of a simple resolution, similar to any other rule of the House. Additionally, provisions regulating action in the congressional budget process may be included in congressional budget resolutions adopted pursuant to the Congressional Budget Act. The Legislative Reorganization Acts of 1946 and 1970 impacted legislative procedures and rulemaking in the Senate, with many provisions later incorporated into the Senate's standing rules. Congressional budget resolutions may also contain provisions regulating action in the budget process. The Legislative Reorganization Acts of 1946 and 1970 influenced legislative procedures and rulemaking in the Senate, with many provisions later included in the Senate's standing rules. Rulemaking statutes specify legislative procedures for the Senate or House in connection with the consideration of specific types of measures. The term rulemaking statute is often used in connection with laws specifying legislative procedures for the Senate or House, such as "expedited procedures" or "fast track" provisions. These define special procedures for congressional approval or disapproval of actions proposed by the executive branch or independent agencies, like the Congressional Review Act. The term "expedited procedures" or "fast track" provisions in rulemaking statutes define special procedures for congressional approval or disapproval of actions proposed by the executive branch or independent agencies. One example is the Congressional Review Act, which allows Congress to overturn a rule issued by a federal agency. Some expedited procedures are listed in the Senate Manual under "General and Permanent Laws Relating to the U.S. Senate." The Congressional Review Act allows Congress to overturn federal agency rules using special procedures listed in the Senate Manual. Key rulemaking statutes define procedures for budgetary legislation consideration, such as the Congressional Budget Act, Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, Budget Enforcement Act, and Budget Control Act. The Congressional Budget Act, Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act, Budget Enforcement Act, and Budget Control Act provide procedures for budgetary legislation consideration. The Congressional Budget Act defines Senate floor procedures for the budget resolution, establishing a budget plan for the fiscal year between the House and Senate. The Budget Act outlines Senate floor procedures for the congressional budget resolution, establishing a budget plan for the fiscal year. The Senate often includes supplementary procedural regulations in the resolution to govern subsequent action on spending bills or other budget-related measures. These provisions create new points of order against budgetary measures or provisions. The budget resolution includes supplementary procedural regulations to govern subsequent action on spending bills or other budget-related measures. These provisions establish new points of order, such as "pay-as-you-go" procedures for Senate consideration of legislation affecting direct spending and revenues. The procedures may be temporary or permanent. The budget resolution includes supplementary procedural regulations, such as "pay-as-you-go" procedures for Senate consideration of legislation affecting direct spending and revenues. These procedures may be temporary or permanent and are not comprehensively compiled in a single source. Procedures in congressional budget resolutions can be temporary or permanent, established through further action in subsequent resolutions. The rules of the Senate conferences, though not adopted by the Senate itself, can impact proceedings on topics like party leader selection and committee assignments. Congress.gov is the official website for U.S. federal legislative information, providing accurate and timely access to documents. Congress.gov is the official website for U.S. federal legislative information, offering accurate and timely access to documents such as nominations, public laws, communications, and treaties. It is presented by the Library of Congress using data from the Office of the Clerk of the U.S. House of Representatives and the Office of the Secretary of the Senate. Congress.gov provides access to legislative information for Members of Congress, legislative agencies, and the public. It includes data from various government offices and covers topics such as nominations, public laws, communications, and treaties. Govinfo.gov, a service of the GPO, offers public access to official publications of the Congress.
